Thanks Jim,
Yes I did intend to attach a photo, sorry I might get the hang =
of technology in another 30 or 40 years. I have put the image in the album =
(I think) under paulb. Please take a look and let me know if its there and =
what you think.
many thanks
paul

Jim Gilbert <jggilbert@...> wro=
te:
Paul,
A thick, round rim is typical for early Akasaka guards.  Later on=
es tend to be thinner.  The early Akasaka really favored a very "high," rou=
nded rim compared with other groups working at the same time.

Sometimes te=
kkotsu are seen in early examples.  Senkotsu is more common, which is a sor=
t of long linear bone that forms where the inner and outer plates are joine=
d.  

I'm not sure if you intended there to be an attached photo.  The list=
 doesn't permit attachments, but you can post images in the group photo alb=
um at:
http://groups.yahoo.com/group/nihontostudy/

Log in and click on the=
 "Photos" link at the left.  I can provide detailed instructions for anyone=
 who would like to learn how to post photos. It's quite easy.

Jim 



  De=
ar All,
  I have been discussing the tsuba below with a number of friends f=
rom both this and another group. The concensus to date is that this is earl=
y Akasaka. While I am more than content with that attribution I was wonderi=
ng how common the thick round mimi was in Aakasaka work? Also there are a l=
ot of bones in the mimi. I understand that early Akasaka work was influence=
d by Owari tsuba, is this an example of this? or should I be looking in ano=
ther direction.
  All comments greatly appreciated.
